channel.title: Lifestyle on Portfolio website of Josephine Haag
channel.description: Recent content in Lifestyle on Portfolio website of Josephine Haag

item.title: Alcohol consumption
item.description: Alcohol all around the world - where do people drink the most alcohol? While some people might argue that drinking alcohol can provide several health benefits, others believe that you should never drink at all. Regardless of this discussion, where do people drink the most alcohol? And how does this differ by alcohol type. The following visualizations provide answers on regional trends for alcohol preference:

item.title: Employee Data
item.description: IBM HR Analytics: Employee satisfaction and income During my internship at an HR Tech start-up Leapsome (leapsome.com) I learned a lot about the importance of employee retention and employee satisfaction. Employee engagement and meaningful feedback, for example, are two drivers of productive employees. This data set on past and current employees at a company can give insights about what can contribute to workforce attrition.

item.title: GDP Components
item.description: Challenge: GDP components over time and among countries After cleaning the dataset, I will try to reproduce a given graph with a different theme and then analyze the different GDP components across countries # tidy data and convert to long format tidy_GDP_data <- UN_GDP_data %>% pivot_longer(cols = c('1970':'2017'), names_to = "Year", values_to = "Amount") %>% rename(Components = IndicatorName) %>% # Components [Components == "Exports of goods and services"] <- "Exports" # rename indicators mutate(Components = case_when( Components == "Final consumption expenditure" ~ "Final consumption", Components == "Household consumption expenditure (including Non-profit institutions serving households)" ~ "Household expenditure", Components == "General government final consumption expenditure" ~ "Government expenditure", Components == "Gross capital formation" ~ "Gross capital formation", Components == "Gross fixed capital formation (including Acquisitions less disposals of valuables)" ~ "Gross fixed capital", Components == "Changes in inventories" ~ "Inventory change", Components == "Exports of goods and services" ~ "Exports", Components == "Imports of goods and services" ~ "Imports", Components == "Gross Domestic Product (GDP)" ~ "GDP", Components == "Agriculture, hunting, forestry, fishing (ISIC A-B)" ~ "ISIC A-B", Components == "Mining, Manufacturing, Utilities (ISIC C-E)" ~ "ISIC C-E", Components == "Manufacturing (ISIC D)" ~ "ISIC D", Components == "Construction (ISIC F)" ~ "ISIC F", Components == "Wholesale, retail trade, restaurants and hotels (ISIC G-H)" ~ "ISIC G-H", Components == "Transport, storage and communication (ISIC I)" ~ "ISIC I", Components == "Other Activities (ISIC J-P)" ~ "ISIC J-P", Components == "Total Value Added" ~ "TVA")) %>% mutate(Amount = (Amount / 1e9)) # divide to express data in billions glimpse(tidy_GDP_data) ## Rows: 176,880 ## Columns: 5 ## $ CountryID <dbl> 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4… ## $ Country <chr> "Afghanistan", "Afghanistan", "Afghanistan", "Afghanistan"… ## $ Components <chr> "Final consumption", "Final consumption", "Final consumpti… ## $ Year <chr> "1970", "1971", "1972", "1973", "1974", "1975", "1976", "1… ## $ Amount <dbl> 5.

item.title: GDP Components
item.description: Challenge: GDP components over time and among countries After cleaning the dataset, I will try to reproduce a given graph with a different theme and then analyze the different GDP components across countries # tidy data and convert to long format tidy_GDP_data <- UN_GDP_data %>% pivot_longer(cols = c('1970':'2017'), names_to = "Year", values_to = "Amount") %>% rename(Components = IndicatorName) %>% # Components [Components == "Exports of goods and services"] <- "Exports" # rename indicators mutate(Components = case_when( Components == "Final consumption expenditure" ~ "Final consumption", Components == "Household consumption expenditure (including Non-profit institutions serving households)" ~ "Household expenditure", Components == "General government final consumption expenditure" ~ "Government expenditure", Components == "Gross capital formation" ~ "Gross capital formation", Components == "Gross fixed capital formation (including Acquisitions less disposals of valuables)" ~ "Gross fixed capital", Components == "Changes in inventories" ~ "Inventory change", Components == "Exports of goods and services" ~ "Exports", Components == "Imports of goods and services" ~ "Imports", Components == "Gross Domestic Product (GDP)" ~ "GDP", Components == "Agriculture, hunting, forestry, fishing (ISIC A-B)" ~ "ISIC A-B", Components == "Mining, Manufacturing, Utilities (ISIC C-E)" ~ "ISIC C-E", Components == "Manufacturing (ISIC D)" ~ "ISIC D", Components == "Construction (ISIC F)" ~ "ISIC F", Components == "Wholesale, retail trade, restaurants and hotels (ISIC G-H)" ~ "ISIC G-H", Components == "Transport, storage and communication (ISIC I)" ~ "ISIC I", Components == "Other Activities (ISIC J-P)" ~ "ISIC J-P", Components == "Total Value Added" ~ "TVA")) %>% mutate(Amount = (Amount / 1e9)) # divide to express data in billions glimpse(tidy_GDP_data) ## Rows: 176,880 ## Columns: 5 ## $ CountryID <dbl> 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4… ## $ Country <chr> "Afghanistan", "Afghanistan", "Afghanistan", "Afghanistan"… ## $ Components <chr> "Final consumption", "Final consumption", "Final consumpti… ## $ Year <chr> "1970", "1971", "1972", "1973", "1974", "1975", "1976", "1… ## $ Amount <dbl> 5.

item.title: Social Media
item.description: SOCIAL MEDIA The General Social Survey (GSS) gathers data on American society in order to monitor and explain trends in attitudes, behaviours, and attributes. Many trends have been tracked for decades, so one can see the evolution of attitudes, etc in American Society. In the following, I will look into the users of different social medias in the US. Overview # calculate the proportions snapchat gss_prop_snap <- gss %>% filter(snapchat!

item.title: Ipsum
item.description: Nullam et orci eu lorem consequat tincidunt vivamus et sagittis magna sed nunc rhoncus condimentum sem. In efficitur ligula tate urna. Maecenas massa sed magna lacinia magna pellentesque lorem ipsum dolor. Nullam et orci eu lorem consequat tincidunt. Vivamus et sagittis tempus.

datadrivencv The goal of datadrivencv is to ease the burden of maintaining a CV by separating the content from the output by treating entries as data. Installation The development version from GitHub with: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("nstrayer/datadrivencv") Motivation Updating a CV is not fun Anytime I would go to add something to my CV I ended up wanting to change the format a tiny bit. This usually meant the entire word document completely falling apart and needing to have each entry copied and pasted into a new version.
